data.value: Classifications of risks, threats and harms for risk assessment & mitigation.

data.name: e6104153
data.value: Earthquake, flood, storm, pollution, fire, incidents;

data.name: e6104156
data.value: Destruction, sabotage, diversion,espionage, war destruction, fraud, steeling, viruses.

data.name: e6104157
data.value: A security threat that uses the insufficient (and often nonexistent) protection of physical communication channels (e.g. wires, communication cables) with purpose to eartapp the communications pathways (and in combination with this illegal data access)

data.name: e6104158
data.value: Different types of extortions from persons that have access to (classified) information necessary for information system security breach.

data.name: e6104159
data.value: Illegal copying and use of software.

data.name: e6104160
data.value: Threats that are focused on data confidentiality, availability and integrity.

data.name: e6104161
data.value: As already mentioned before this security threat is focused on limiting the functionality and availability of information system resources. Availability of information system resources, in the context of information system security, assumes that all capabilities of information system resources, like information system infrastructure, software, etc. will be available for authorized user. Degradation of IS services can be caused on many different ways [17.] 􀂱 physical assault, backup systems malfunction, natural disasters. what all can result with a physical damage to the information system, etc.

data.name: e6104162
data.value: Security threat that is not illegal because it is based on searching through garbage 􀂱 unwanted and discarded resources. It is interesting that this type of security threat can lead to serious damage, because in garbage different resources, like un-erased data media, non-shredded paper documents, etc., and indirectly many information valuable for organization, can be found

data.name: e6104163
data.value: The intruder tries to and guess the user's password, and then to use this password for unauthorized activities. This attack can be conducted manually and automatically. This way in relatively short period of time large number of possible password candidates can be checked.

data.name: e6104164
data.value: Also known as "false identity" is a type of security threat where one person uses the identity of another person with purpose to gain access to information system infrastructure. Masquerading can be physical (use of authorized user's identity and/or user's identity card), and electronically (use of electronic user's identity with purpose to log in the information system).

data.name: e6104165
data.value: Different ways of manipulations with purpose to gain access to useful information (user names, passwords, business secrets, etc.) that can be used to endanger the information system security

data.name: e6104166
data.value: Different types of malware software that was described in the previous sections (e.g. computer viruses, worms, Trojan horses, back doors, timed attacks, hoaxes).

data.name: e6104167
data.value: Also known as false data entry is basically unauthorized change of data entry prior, during or after the data store in information system.

data.name: e6104168
data.value: A type of security threat in which attackers will gain wanted data by using weaknesses of Internet and insufficient attention of the users.

data.name: e6104169
data.value: Threat that use malicious software with purpose to sniff 􀂱 to exam the network traffic in search for part in which user names and passwords are exchanged

data.name: e6104170
data.value: Threat that use malicious software with purpose to search the network systems for information that are used for unauthorized activities.

data.name: e6104171
data.value: Threat that rise from the administrator and privileged user rights and their misuse.

data.name: e6110012
data.value: • GREEN - Where an assessment outcome is Green, we still work to see if we can develop and implement any solutions or mitigating actions that can be applied to reduce the risk impact down as far as possible. However, most green rated risks are acceptable and so focus should be placed on those with higher ratings. Even where a green RAG rating has been given at the risk/privacy identification stage, this risk will still be added to the mitigating actions template for continuity and to ensure that all risks have been recorded and assessed. • AMBER - Where an assessment outcome is Amber, mitigating actions are always proposed and outcomes envisaged, before processing is approved. The aim is to reduce all risks down to a green (acceptable) level, however there will be occasions when processing must take place for legal/best interest reasons and so some processing with risks will go ahead and must be accepted into the project. All solutions and mitigating actions must first be considered, tried and applied if possible. If the risk is associated with the processing of personal data, the risk should be escalated to the Data Impact Assessment screening questions to ascertain if a complete DPIA is required. • RED - Where an assessment outcome is Red, it indicates that either or both impact and/or likelihood scores are unacceptable, and that complete solutions and mitigating actions would be required to bring both indicators down to an acceptable level. Some activities are eliminated at this point as the impact is considered to high risk to proceed. However, in instances where the activity or project is essential or is a legal requirement, the proposed solutions and mitigating actions are applied, and a further risk assessment carried out to see if the risk score can be reduced to an acceptable.

data.name: e6110013
data.value: • GREEN - Where an assessment outcome is Green, we still work to see if we can develop and implement any solutions or mitigating actions that can be applied to reduce the risk impact down as far as possible. However, most green rated risks are acceptable and so focus should be placed on those with higher ratings. Even where a green RAG rating has been given at the risk/privacy identification stage, this risk will still be added to the mitigating actions template for continuity and to ensure that all risks have been recorded and assessed. • AMBER - Where an assessment outcome is Amber, mitigating actions are always proposed and outcomes envisaged, before processing is approved. The aim is to reduce all risks down to a green (acceptable) level, however there will be occasions when processing must take place for legal/best interest reasons and so some processing with risks will go ahead and must be accepted into the project. All solutions and mitigating actions must first be considered, tried and applied if possible. If the risk is associated with the processing of personal data, the risk should be escalated to the Data Impact Assessment screening questions to ascertain if a complete DPIA is required. • RED - Where an assessment outcome is Red, it indicates that either or both impact and/or likelihood scores are unacceptable, and that complete solutions and mitigating actions would be required to bring both indicators down to an acceptable level. Some activities are eliminated at this point as the impact is considered to high risk to proceed. However, in instances where the activity or project is essential or is a legal requirement, the proposed solutions and mitigating actions are applied, and a further risk assessment carried out to see if the risk score can be reduced to an acceptable.

data.name: e6105141
data.value: The Data Protection Directive 95/46/EC, which saw the UK enact the Data Protection Act 1998, was an EU Directive, unlike the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) (Regulation (EU)2016/679), which is a Regulation. An EU Directive applies to all Member States and sets specific aims, requirements and results that must be achieved by every State through the drafting and enactment of their own national law. Each Member State is free to decide how to transpose the Directive into law, providing the result is achieved and aims met. An EU Regulation is a legally binding legislation Act that applies to each Member State and must be followed directly. A Regulation comes into force on a specified date for all States simultaneously and enables standardisation and consistency.

data.name: e6105142
data.value: kept in a form which permits identification of data subjects for no longer than is necessary for the purposes for which the personal data are processed (‘storage limitation’)

data.name: e6105143
data.value: processed in a manner that ensures appropriate security of the personal data, including protection against unauthorised or unlawful processing and against accidental loss, destruction or damage, using appropriate technical or organisational measures (‘integrity and confidentiality’)

data.name: e6105146
data.value: Being transparent and providing the legal information about personal data collection and processing in an accessible format, is one of the key areas of the GDPR and is fundamental to an individual’s right to be informed. The most common way of providing this information is via a Privacy Notice. A Privacy Notice can also be known as a privacy policy or a consent notice and is a legal statement or document that discloses the required information to the data subject about how their data will be used, why, what for, when and for how long. The exact disclosure information under the GDPR is provided in Articles 13 and 14. Where the data is intended to be used for direct marketing purposes, the data subject must be able to opt-out of the marketing option without it affecting their rights or the specified purpose of the processing. Where a controller relies on consent to obtain and process personal information, they must ensure that the disclosure information and Privacy Notice is: - • Displayed clearly and prominently • Asks individuals to positively opt-in • Gives them sufficient information to make an informed choice • Explains the different ways that their information will be used • Provides a clear and simple way for them to indicate they agree to different types of processing • Includes a separate, unticked opt-in box for direct marketing

data.name: e6105147
data.value: The right to data portability is a new right to UK data protection law and enables individuals to obtain their personal data in a structured, commonly used, machine readable format, thus allowing them to share and reuse their personal data for their own purposes across different services. A data subject can also authorise a controller to share personal information via an automated means with a third party of their choice. This enables individuals to reuse data and saves time and cost in copying and resending personal data that is already available. Controllers must keep a machine-readable version of all personal information (where possible), which can include the below formats: - • CSV • HTML • XML • RDF • XHTML

data.name: e6105148

data.name: e6105149

data.name: e6105150

data.name: e6105151
